16:
**Project Management Checklist**
```json
[
  {"page": "Import Excel File", 
   ["function": "Read Excel File", 
    "description": "A batch program will read the subject list from 'Spring Semester Subjects.xlsx'."]},
   { "function": "Assign Header Fields", 
    "description": "Identify the header fields: '#' (id), 'Name', 'Weekday', and 'Time'."},
  {"page": "Pivot Subject Table",  
   ["function": "Create PivotTable", 
    "description": "Transpose table to create a two-dimensional subject schedule using Weekday, Time, and Name."]},

   { "function": "Output Transformed Schedule", 
    "description": "Output transformed subject schedule into 'Transformed Subjects.xlsx' under the same directory."}
]
```

Batch Program:
**`subject_pivot.vbs`**

```vb
Dim xlApp, xlWorkBook, xlWorksheet

' Create a late binding to Excel for automation
Set xlApp = CreateObject("Excel.Application")

with xlApp

    ' Set your .xlsx file path here
    Set xlWorkbook = .Workbooks.Open _
        ("C:\\Path\\To\\Spring Semester Subjects.xlsx")

    With xlWorkbook.Worksheets(1)
        ' Identify header rows
        Dim headers() As Variant: headers = Array("#", "Name", "Weekday", "Time")
        
        For i = 1 To Range(headers(3)).Cells.Count
            Select Case cells(i, 4).Value2
                Case "First period" : .cells(i, 5).Value2 = "9:00-10:45"
                Case "Second period" : .cells(i, 5).Value2 = "11:15-12:55"
                Case "Third period" : .cells(i, 5).Value2 = "14:40-16:20"
                Case "Fourth period" : .cells(i, 5).Value2 = "17:50-19:30"
            End Select
        Next i

        ' Transform into two-dimensional subject table
        Dim rng As Range: Set rng = sheets("Sheet1").Range("A1:E100") 
        With rng
            .Name = "TransformedSubjectSchedule"  ' name for the formula
            '.FormulaArray = Array( _
            '    "=IF(RC[-5]="""",RC[-4],"""""
            '          )", _
            '    "TRANSPOSE()", _
            '
            '
            Set arrFormulaRng = rows(1, .Cells.Count).Cells  ' Create an array formula for the range
                For i = 0 To arrFormulaRng.Cells.Count - 1
                    With arrFormulaRng.Cells(i)
                        With .offset(0, -4)  '.offset returns a new Ranges object relative to current reference point (or cell A1 in this scenario)
                            '   The pivot expression for each column
                            If WorksheetFunction.IsNumber(.Value2) Then _
                                Application.Transpose(ThisWorkbook.Sheets("Sheet1").Evaluate(
                                    "TRANSPOSE{ IF( 
    """ & Trim(.Value2) & ""=""", """"" "", TRANSPOSE({" & _

                                                Switch(Type = If(IsWeekday=Monday, 1, 
                                                                                      Type = If(IsWeekday=Tuesday, 2, 

                                                                                          Type= If(IsWeekday=Wednesday, 3,
                                                                                                Type=If(IsWeekday=Thursday,4,
                                                                                                                                   True)) ))



                                ").Value), _
                                    "},{ IF( """ & Trim(.Value)  & """="" ,""""" """, TRANSPOSE({" &
                                        "First period" & ", '9:00-10:45'" & "; 
                                        If Type = If(IsWeekday=Monday, 1 , Is_weekday_tuesday=2 , type_is_WendnesDay=3 , _ 
                                         ) True : IF(Type_=If(IsweghDay_Thursday,4,true))"

                              : "})}, """
                                """)"}


                objExcel.Visible = False  ' hide excel application in background for automation without displaying the Excel app on screen

        End With
```
Save above script to a file (with .vbs extension). It can run automatically.
